snippet.textDisplay:
They've been promising smaller hydrogen fuel cells since I was barely a teen; they've been promising them for over twenty years by my memory. I haven't seen any progress there. On the other hand, batteries have gotten measurably better. But I will also note that it's easy and known technology to fit the entire hydrogen fuel cell package (fuel to electricity) into a shipping container.


I think the best path forward is to convert old gas stations into fuel cell powered charge stations for BEV cars. Each charge charge station would have at least two large fuel cells in a self contained shipping container so that when one cell is low on hydrogen, a new one can swapped in without interruption to service.
snippet.textOriginal:
They've been promising smaller hydrogen fuel cells since I was barely a teen; they've been promising them for over twenty years by my memory. I haven't seen any progress there. On the other hand, batteries have gotten measurably better. But I will also note that it's easy and known technology to fit the entire hydrogen fuel cell package (fuel to electricity) into a shipping container.


I think the best path forward is to convert old gas stations into fuel cell powered charge stations for BEV cars. Each charge charge station would have at least two large fuel cells in a self contained shipping container so that when one cell is low on hydrogen, a new one can swapped in without interruption to service.

That's the main difference.

snippet.textDisplay: Both cars prove the point that capitalism only wants to sustain itself. You have to buy electricity or hydrogen to power them and will only be at the whim of the new and improved version of the oil industry.  Internal combustion engines can run on hydrogen just fine. The hydrogen can be extracted from water by an electric current that is produced by the running engine while driving. This has been done over and over. But it can't be allowed because there would be no money to be made by the big fat corporations and Wall Street.

snippet.textDisplay:
James May is the one out of the three who's opinion I respect the most. However, he's a bit late to the debate. Hydrogen is toast in passenger vehicles because it's so darn expensive and can't get cheaper due to poor efficiency of hydrogen as an energy carrier. Maybe if you don't care about money that's a non-issue for you but then why do you also want a slow car? HVDC fast charging is improving all the time and it won't be too many more years before we see road trip pit stops of ~10 minutes for another 4+ hours of driving. A 10 minute roadtriping pit stop vs a 2 minute stop is a trade-off most average people will be happy to make especially if it means that they only pay 1/3 as much to refuel. Moreso when they realize that for the bulk of their ownership experience they won't even have to make ANY visits to a 'fuel' station: they'll simply plug in at home, overnight, or at work. A FCEV will require a weekly errand to the pump and a vacuum cleaner draining your wallet for as long as you own it.



Ocean going ships are another issue. It's more conceivable that they may go hydrogen. However, hydrogen is still (and will always be) an expensive fuel. Hydrogen will also be competing in this space with other technologies such as net zero synthetic fuels, or even flow batteries. Ultimately, the most cost effective energy storage mechanism will rule the waves. Could be hydrogen, but that's not a sure thing at all.
snippet.textOriginal:
James May is the one out of the three who's opinion I respect the most.  However, he's a bit late to the debate.  Hydrogen is toast in passenger vehicles because it's so darn expensive and can't get cheaper due to poor efficiency of hydrogen as an energy carrier.  Maybe if you don't care about money that's a non-issue for you but then why do you also want a slow car?  HVDC fast charging is improving all the time and it won't be too many more years before we see road trip pit stops of ~10 minutes for another 4+ hours of driving.  A 10 minute roadtriping pit stop vs a 2 minute stop is a trade-off most average people will be happy to make especially if it means that they only pay 1/3 as much to refuel.  Moreso when they realize that for the bulk of their ownership experience they won't even have to make ANY visits to a 'fuel' station: they'll simply plug in at home, overnight, or at work.  A FCEV will require a weekly errand to the pump and a vacuum cleaner draining your wallet for as long as you own it.



Ocean going ships are another issue.  It's more conceivable that they may go hydrogen.  However, hydrogen is still (and will always be) an expensive fuel.  Hydrogen will also be competing in this space with other technologies such as net zero synthetic fuels, or even flow batteries.  Ultimately, the most cost effective energy storage mechanism will rule the waves.  Could be hydrogen, but that's not a sure thing at all.

snippet.textDisplay:
I like this and agree, but one thing is missing from the hydrogen point, these fuel stations need a break between each filling, 5-10minutes just to repressurize for the next car.
From the BEV point of view - with teslas purchase of maxwell, they can now provide more regen recovery aswell as blast charge the ultra capacitors, meaning much faster charging. The technology they bring too removes wet solvents from the batery chemestry, which was recently found to produce dendrites/the reason you lose capacity. This tech also reduces the volumetric size of the battery per kwh.

snippet.textDisplay: Solar and wind are pointless. Even if they were viable sources of energy, why use anything other than the two massively successful and efficient sources of energy, nuclear? The only reason they are being advocated for is due to activist environmentalism. Geo and hydrological environmentalism leaves only one answer in the long term, nuclear power, until there is something even better that is just as practical. The whole climate debate is irrelevant, we are going to run out of fossil fuel, maybe 50 or at the most 100 years from now. Until we have an energy efficient means of transporting more fossil fuels back from extraterrestrial sources, nuclear power is all we have. Also geothermal power, highly underutilized.
snippet.textOriginal: Solar and wind are pointless. Even if they were viable sources of energy, why use anything other than the two massively successful and efficient sources of energy, nuclear? The only reason they are being advocated for is due to activist environmentalism. Geo and hydrological environmentalism leaves only one answer in the long term, nuclear power, until there is something even better that is just as practical. The whole climate debate is irrelevant, we are going to run out of fossil fuel, maybe 50 or at the most 100 years from now. snippet.textDisplay: I'm at a bit of a loss here, because I can see both sides to this. Batteries are incredibly versatile and powerful now. They are getting smaller and more energy dense every day. And efficiency going from power station, or even better, solar panels, is damn near 90%. But it's hard to argue with two minute fill up, light weight, and long range. The infrastructure issue? Is a nonissue. People said Tesla would never be able to build a charging infrastructure. Those chargers are everywhere today. So saying you can't build a viable hydrogen infrastructure, is extremely naive. But at the same time, is it cheaper and more efficient to simply capitalize on the existing power grid to expand the charging network, rather than build out a complex and potentially dangerous distribution system for yet more highly explosive substances? Yes. I'm just not sure anymore.
snippet.textOriginal: I'm at a bit of a loss here, because I can see both sides to this. Batteries are incredibly versatile and powerful now. They are getting smaller and more energy dense every day. And efficiency going from power station, or even better, solar panels, is damn near 90%. But it's hard to argue with two minute fill up, light weight, and long range. The infrastructure issue? Is a nonissue. People said Tesla would never be able to build a charging infrastructure. Those chargers are everywhere today. So saying you can't build a viable hydrogen infrastructure, is extremely naive. But at the same time, is it cheaper and more efficient to simply capitalize on the existing power grid to expand the charging network, rather than build out a complex and potentially dangerous distribution system for yet more highly explosive substances? Yes. I'm just not sure anymore.

snippet.textDisplay: Not only would inductive charging in the street require massive infrastructure, but inductive charging is massively inefficient and that gets worse with distance.  Just charging your phone from a wireless charging pad works at about 50% efficiency and that's the phone in direct contact with the pad.  Switching to electric cars to solve the energy crisis, only to spaff 70% of the electricity up the wall by using inductive charging, is an exercise in lunacy.
snippet.textOriginal: Not only would inductive charging in the street require massive infrastructure, but inductive charging is massively inefficient and that gets worse with distance.  Just charging your phone from a wireless charging pad works at about 50% efficiency and that's the phone in direct contact with the pad.  Switching to electric cars to solve the energy crisis, only to spaff 70% of the electricity up the wall by using inductive charging, is an exercise in lunacy.

snippet.textDisplay:
Issue is the average person in the UK probably can't afford a Tesla. I know I can't.
I buy decent 10-15 year old cars and do the maintenance myself as they are still simple enough to work on. I wouldn't personally buy a car on finance and I don't have the capital available to buy a second hand one and replace the batteries at immense cost.
Totally unrealistic for the common family.

Let me add some...
"In the future, energy will be abundant, so it won't matter that Hydrogen is wasteful". -- "Yes, but in the future, we'll all be dead".

So the Tesla cost 7.8p per mile when charging at one of the expensive chargers (it's cheaper at home) - in a 400+bhp saloon that's amazing - for comparison most equivalent petrol cars cost about 32p per mile in fuel - over 4 times as much!!

EDIT - so the hydrogen is 20.5p per mile - probably more than a petrol car with equivalent power (about 150hp)

snippet.textDisplay: Guess what ... hydrogen fuel cells cars have batteries! You don't even avoid battery use if you buy one. And you can't really buy one ... there were 15 Mirais available to UK buyers this year. Tesla alone sold 3,500 cars just in September 2019! Once we have an oversupply of electricity from cheap renewables let's look again, but that's likely to decades away. Meantime let's keep fuel cell development going but it's going to be a niche product for a while yet.
snippet.textOriginal: Guess what ... hydrogen fuel cells cars have batteries! You don't even avoid battery use if you buy one. And you can't really buy one ... there were 15 Mirais available to UK buyers this year. Tesla alone sold 3,500 cars just in September 2019! Once we have an oversupply of electricity from cheap renewables let's look again, but that's likely to decades away. Meantime let's keep fuel cell development going but it's going to be a niche product for a while yet.

snippet.textDisplay: Very entertaining and informative, but one thing James May left out is that BEVs with solar panels (usually solar roofs) built in are on the way. A quick back of the envelope calculation would indicate that these should give around 20 miles of range on a sunny day, which is incidentally also the average daily commute in most countries. So, solar alone would be enough to keep most cars topped up for the daily commute and then when they go on a longer trip, they can use the growing network of fast chargers. This is a game changer and would mean that HFC vehicles, at least in the passenger car market, would make no sense. Of course, like James mentioned, it may be a different proposition for commercial vehicles, ships, planes, etc...
snippet.textOriginal: Very entertaining and informative, but one thing James May left out is that BEVs with solar panels (usually solar roofs) built in are on the way. A quick back of the envelope calculation would indicate that these should give around 20 miles of range on a sunny day, which is incidentally also the average daily commute in most countries. So, solar alone would be enough to keep most cars topped up for the daily commute and then when they go on a longer trip, they can use the growing network of fast chargers. This is a game changer and would mean that HFC vehicles, at least in the passenger car market, would make no sense. Of course, like James mentioned, it may be a different proposition for commercial vehicles, ships, planes, etc...
